general: Tinidazole is chemically related to Metronidazole and is effective in the therapy of amebiasis, giardiasis and trichomoniasis.
Long half-life allows for intermittent dosing.
In general, Tinidazole is more potent and has fewer adverse reactions than Metronidazole.
Contraindicated in the first trimester, according to some experts.

adult_dose.amebiasis_intestinal: 2 gm po once daily x 3 days
adult_dose.amebiasis_liver_abscess: 2 gm po once daily x 5 days
adult_dose.trichomoniasis: 2 gm po x 1 dose; treat sex partner at same time
adult_dose.bacterial_vaginosis: 2 gm po once daily x 2 days, or 1 gm once daily x 5 days

pediatric_dose.amebic_liver_abscess: Age >3 yrs: 50 mg/kg q24h x3-5 days
pediatric_dose.intestinal_amebiasis: Age >3 yrs: 50 mg/kg q24h x3 days

renal_adjustment.notes: Dosage adjustment may be required in hepatic disease.
renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: No dosage adjustment for renal impairment
renal_adjustment.hemodialysis: No dosage adjustment (give an extra 1 gm AD if administered before dialysis)

adverse_effects: Dysgeusia/metallic taste 4-6%, nausea 3-5%, anorexia 2-3%, vomiting 1.5%. All higher with multi-day dosing. Seizures/peripheral neuropathy reported.
Avoid alcohol during and for 3 days after last dose; can cause disulfiram reaction: flushing, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, sweating and headache.

pregnancy_risk.fda_risk_category: Limited human data, but evidence of toxicity in animals. Contraindicated in 1st trimester, according to some experts.
pregnancy_risk.footnote: Capital letter = Old FDA risk category; Text = New FDA risk category
